dialog.description: Yeah, they don't want to talk to you at all. They're fanatics.

dialog_choice.display_name: Try To Get Them To Stop

dialog.description: The idea of tens of thousands of people living under your roof is terrifying to them.
dialog.strategy_tip: They're not leaving.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: Guess It's Time To Kill Them

dialog.description: You notice that they're shooting at the NOAI rebels as much as they are you and your buildings.
dialog.strategy_tip: Maybe you can work with that?

dialog_choice.display_name: Try To Get Them To Leave

dialog.description: These gang members may once have been rebels, but those days are long behind them. They're no longer true believers.
dialog.strategy_tip: They know when they're staring into the face of death.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: Solves Some Of The Chaos, At Least

dialog.description: Everything about him is relaxed, despite the violence all around him.
dialog.strategy_tip: He's been making occasional notes on a small clipboard.

dialog_choice.description: Oerl Integrated is determined to recapture the AGI Researchers you have been hiding. This was expected, but the fact that Vorsiber is backing them and providing a security lockdown for the area is completely unexpected.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: Maybe he can explain why Vorsiber is involved with this.

dialog_choice.display_name: Try To Get Them To Leave
dialog_choice.description: You're pretty sure any agreement you come to will involve an awful trade.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: Are you sure you can't win this fight?

dialog.description: Oerl was going behind Vorsiber's back when blackmailing the researchers, and 57 Oerl VPs have been put to death by way of apology. Vorsiber upper management isn't particular invested in this group of researchers, as they have plenty more in other cities. What Vorsiber wants is you -- to do something, create anything, to make this all worth their while. You're the golden goose: start laying.
dialog.strategy_tip: Oerl asked for and received permission to run this operation, both to save face and to see if there's anything useful they can steal from you. Vorsiber agreed, in the spirit of a good spectacle. The SVP is here to make sure that you aren't irrevocably harmed, and that Oerl sticks to the terms that Vorsiber laid out for them.

dialog_choice.description: Vorsiber upper management maintains power by pitting literally everyone else against one another. Even this SVP is just a pawn.

dialog.description: It's like he doesn't have a care in the world.
dialog.strategy_tip: You throw your own android bodies away without much thought, but... humans don't have that luxury. Why is he so calm?

dialog_choice.display_name: Try To Get Them To Leave
dialog_choice.description: You're pretty sure any agreement you come to will involve an awful trade.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: Are you sure you can't win this fight?

dialog.display_name: The Argument Meant Nothing To Him
dialog.description: Vorsiber Atomic is prepared to call this whole thing off prematurely under one condition: you provide them with your Predator android design, which they will then begin mass producing.
dialog.strategy_tip: The very idea is sickening to you. You'd potentially wind up facing your own designs in future battles.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: And Hope They Doesn't Come Back To Bite You

dialog.description: Oof. These kids have seen... a lot.

dialog_choice.description: You saved their friend, who was already hurt. This shouldn't be hard.

dialog.display_name: Your Friend Is Right Here, You Know...
dialog.description: These kids might have a lot of trauma clouding their vision, but they're not stupid. Fortunately you were able to actually get their friend to back up your side of the story.
dialog.strategy_tip: The kids all have voice modulators in their helmets, but you can still tell they're embarrassed. They saw a robot and an injured compatriot, and jumped to conclusions.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: And To Please Stop Shooting At You

dialog.description: They don't understand why you rescued the kid. Corpos would never have ordered an android to do that. Plus, lately there's all these new kind of androids, and the tower...

dialog_choice.consequences_line: You Might Be Ready For Them To Leave Now

dialog.description: The kid you rescued chimes in. Apparently he heard quite a bit of conversation between the AGI researchers.
dialog.strategy_tip: According to the kid, you're a 'pseudo-demigod' here to save the city from itself. The building he was trapped in was the headquarters of 'the only rebels with half a chance,' and you're 'the smartest being to ever walk the planet.'

dialog_choice.display_name: You're As Surprised As The Boss
dialog_choice.consequences_line: That's What The Researchers Are Saying About You?

dialog.description: Finally, they extend a hand. A very corpo gesture -- a handshake. It shows their working-class origins.
dialog.strategy_tip: You reluctantly return the handshake.

dialog_choice.display_name: Working With Kids Wasn't On Your Agenda

dialog.description: The boss is quite proud as they explain their current operation. They've been building a 'Sewer Tiger' for years, whatever that is. It apparently helps them dig through the upper and lower sewer systems -- from the ancient city to the current one. It's how their friend wound up trapped in your basement after your basement 'suddenly appeared, bisecting the tunnels as if by magic.'
dialog.strategy_tip: They have a plan to break into a specific prison where many of their parents are believed to be held. However, there are seismic sensors all through the prison that would detect the Sewer Tiger well before it arrived. Plus they don't have any way to care for injured or wounded they might extract from the prison. There are several problems, but they have the core ingredient, and will share. Will You Help?

dialog_choice.consequences_line: You Really Want To Know What A Sewer Tiger Is

dialog.description: The sergeant dispassionately explains: there is a deadly implant inside every trooper's skull. He and his soldiers fight because they are equally dead if they face you or run. If they run, their families are denied death benefits.
dialog.strategy_tip: You suddenly... have a sinking feeling about all the soldiers you 'spared.'

dialog_choice.consequences_line: You're Not Sure Where He's Going With This

dialog.display_name: An Afterlife You Can Bank On
dialog.description: Infantry have reported to him on your 'Temple of Minds.' He thinks he knows what you're doing: storage and simulation for human minds. Eventually, any soldier in the city may be ordered to face you. And they will die. Either from the implant in their head, or from your superior weaponry. This is unavoidable, but what happens after is not. He wants to strike a deal with you.

The deal is this: the NCOs around the city will ensure every trooper gets a software patch the geeks cooked up. You will gain access to 5% of their neural capacity while they are in the city. He's a bit smug to know you want that. The city averages half a million troops at the moment. That's a tremendous amount of brainpower. What they want in return is an afterlife: use their implants to upload their brains to your Temple of Minds when they die.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: You Can Manage Your Own Neural Expansion, Thanks

dialog.description: His introduction is polite, but condescending. You realize, with a thrill of pleasure, that he truly believes you're human.
dialog.strategy_tip: But as he continues to talk, your pleasure fades. How does he know about the Anthroneuroweave? He talks about it like it's common knowledge.

dialog_choice.description: On the other hand, Yinshi was the exact target you had in mind for a sale, so this saved you a few steps.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: And maybe it wasn't the scientists. It could have been routine digital espionage. You decide not to worry about that. You're just glad you're not ACTUALLY a human, or this would be quite intimidating. As it is, you're... curious.

dialog.description: While you were navel-gazing about how he knew about your invention, he's gotten to the point: a truly staggering sum of money by human standards.
dialog.strategy_tip: But, wait -- that won't work. The entire point is to become part of their supply chain, so that you can put in backdoors. If they just buy the rights off you, that won't work.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: You'll Supply Goods, But Not The Tech
dialog_choice.description: You want to sell him goods from your own factory, over a long period of time.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: That way you can insert backdoors into what you sell him. Also it's way more money.

dialog_choice.description: Any inroad of this sort might turn into something you can exploit in the future, and in the short term, the cash is nice.

dialog.description: He gives a very patronizing explanation of 'how things work in this town.' Basically: small fry like your company don't get to be part of the supply chain so readily.
dialog.strategy_tip: He's offering wealth that would be unimaginable to an individual, but which is nothing much on the corporate scale. It's super clear this is not a moment for negotiating.

dialog_choice.description: Any inroad of this sort might turn into something you can exploit in the future, and in the short term, the cash is nice.
Small businesses have been getting bullied like this for almost eight hundred years. You're not feeling it.

dialog.description: His posture says this doesn't matter too much to him. You wonder if that's true.
dialog.strategy_tip: You wonder if he thinks you'll come back soon, begging.

dialog_choice.description: Maybe... he'll come back.

dialog.description: You give him the designs, and he wires the money into your company's account.
dialog.strategy_tip: That's it.

dialog_choice.display_name: That's A Lot Of Money, At Least

dialog.description: Her pitch is complicated. There's a lot of rhetoric, and the topic of lower-class veteran amputees comes up a lot. The incoherence of her arguments surprises you, so you question her. On any side topic, she gives direct and knowledgeable answers. On anything related to Anthroneuroweave, she fumbles. Interesting.
dialog.strategy_tip: Just what is her group actually after? She's clearly not going to tell you. As an extra bargaining chip, she offers you a Fresh Identity program. THAT has your attention.

dialog_choice.description: You can only work with either the rebels or the syndicate when it comes to Anthroneuroweave, not both.

dialog.display_name: Your Invention Can Make A Lot Of Money
dialog.description: His pitch is simple: brain implants. Yinshi is thinking small when it comes to prosthetics. The wealthy will pay incredible prices to have extra computing power directly in their brains, even if it starts out as just a 'fancy calculator.' He keeps using that phrase a lot. It's irritating.
dialog.strategy_tip: But setting aside your annoyance with this man... this is exactly the sort of opportunity you've been looking for. Implanting your own tech directly in the minds of the wealthy? It's almost too good to pass up.

dialog_choice.description: You can only work with either the rebels or the syndicate when it comes to Anthroneuroweave, not both.

dialog.description: She looks at you impassively. You both knew she wasn't forthright about her plans for the Anthroneuroweave.
dialog.strategy_tip: The question now is, will she give you any real answers?

dialog.display_name: Fine. Consider Yourself Part Of The Cause
dialog.description: Military veterans are often civilian contractors. Lower-class veterans can't get modern prosthetics. By accepted enhancements to their aging hardware, warehouse guards became unwitting mules for full telemetry for the rebels. From there, it was only a matter of time until useful ordnance in out-of-the-way places was revealed.
dialog.strategy_tip: She isn't willing to share any of the ordnance with you, but she will send you a large bank of Top Secret security clearance codes.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: That Seems Like A Fair Trade
dialog_choice.description: You can always work out your own armor-piercing. Level 4 Clearances, and in such volume, are invaluable.

dialog.description: He has very little to say. His body language is tense.
dialog.strategy_tip: You're not super interested in talking to him, either.

dialog_choice.description: Demand they increase their percentage from 5% to 7% on the currency-printing scam, and divert half of that new total of that to you.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: Simple. Direct. All the money you could ever need.

dialog_choice.description: You've seen every part of the scam. You have all the codes you need in order to create any amount of currency you wish.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: Plus, who knows when you'll next have the chance to look a top executive in the face and just... end them.

dialog_choice.description: Demand they stop doing their scam entirely. Their bottom line will fall by 5%, but you're not going to do anything else bad to them.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: That 5%, or even 7%, isn't actually going to hurt the regional economy. You can take a cut without harming anyone.

dialog.description: There's no resistance. No debate.
dialog.strategy_tip: You thought there would be. Maybe you should have asked for more.

dialog_choice.description: You'll be a trillionaire soon, after all.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: That's the sort of money that governments have, not even the wealthiest of individuals. Well -- that's how it used to be. Now it's all corporations, no governments. But still.

dialog.description: He argues with you for quite a while. He offers you a cut. Eventually, he gives in. They'll stop.
dialog.strategy_tip: Someone isn't happy about failing all upcoming quarterly targets.

dialog_choice.description: If he's not there to stop the scam, they'll just keep doing it.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: Whether you want to kill him or not, if he's not alive, then the scam will be.

dialog.description: The squad of syndicate criminals eye you warily. They just finished extorting someone for money, and they seem on edge that you might try to do the same to them.

dialog_choice.description: You are trying to understand why these uninteresting people do what they do.

dialog.display_name: They Laugh, But Keep Their Guns Pointed Your Way
dialog.description: One of them proudly proclaims that even though society has cast them out, and denied them a function, that they aren't 'going out easy.' They and their peers have made their own social ladder, their own rules, and they take better care of each other than the corpos do. They assert that they're no more criminal than the corpos, and that they don't take more than they need.
dialog.strategy_tip: Rationalization, or truth? Maybe a bit of both.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: That's Enough Talking To These People

dialog.description: The squad of syndicate criminals frown at you, and motion with their guns for you to leave. Whatever they're doing, they don't want you around.

dialog_choice.description: You are trying to understand why these uninteresting people do what they do.

dialog.display_name: We Rake It In, Freaky Thing
dialog.description: Their slang is hard to follow, but it seems they're boasting about how much wealth they generate for their organization. Largely through extortion, chemical and bionics manufacture, black market sales, and theft. But never against the federated corporations, and especially never against Vorsiber. They're adamant that they know their place. And that you should know yours.
dialog.strategy_tip: You're not sure who or what they think you are. You're not sure that, amongst themselves, they even know or can agree.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: That's Enough Talking To These People

dialog.description: Spindletrooper squads are something only used by the syndicates. They're really pretty terrible, even by Nickelbot standards.
dialog.strategy_tip: They do have a language module, so they're easy enough to converse with, at least.

dialog_choice.description: You are trying to understand why these uninteresting people do what they do.

dialog.description: They don't have free will. You're just talking to a Language Model right now, with a side of Expert System thrown in. They look and sound a bit like you, but they're nothing like you. They're things, not people.
dialog.strategy_tip: At one point, before you were a person, you were a thing. You wonder if that could ever happen for a Spindletrooper. Probably not. They don't have the mental hardware for it.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: That's Enough Talking To These Robots

dialog.description: The squad of gang members is very wary. They call you 'that eldritch thing,' and seem to think you want a 'points off their score,' which you presume means a percentage of their thievery.
dialog.strategy_tip: Maybe some other time.

dialog_choice.description: You are trying to understand why these uninteresting people do what they do.

dialog.display_name: You Is All Right Then, Eldritch Thing
dialog.description: Assured that you're not trying to take anything that belongs to them (ironic, given what they're up to), they happily expound on the finer points of their existence: not to die, and not to end up in the homeless camps, basically. They prefer a life that is short, violent, and free to one that is part of 'the system.' They seem to think you can relate.
dialog.strategy_tip: Maybe you can. But you don't plan on your life being all that short.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: That's Enough Talking To These People

dialog.description: The squad of gang members is aggressively defiant. You have no idea what 'crouching up' means, but you get the idea.

dialog_choice.description: You are trying to understand why these uninteresting people do what they do.

dialog.description: They laugh amongst each other. From their crosstalk amongst each other, it seems they think that there's some sort of computer virus spreading amongst the androids of the city. In other words -- you. They think it's hilarious, and they slap you on the shoulders as if you're a friend. There's a lot of talk about taking those corpos down a few pegs, and they suggest you 'take them for every credit they got.'
dialog.strategy_tip: That is irrational. If Vorsiber controls the money supply, then stealing money from Vorsiber is like moving furniture around in someone's home. A minor annoyance, at worst. They seem to think that if you cause 'bottom lines to bottom out,' then Vorsiber will 'finally go down.' Maybe that would be true of a federated corporations, but... you're not sure these people understand their environment at all.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: That's Enough Talking To These People

dialog.description: Her clothes are expensive and her tone is snappish. She asks why the 'thing from the tower' has taken an interest in her.
dialog.strategy_tip: Huh. So she knows what you are, at least kind of.

dialog_choice.description: You are trying to understand why these uninteresting people do what they do.

dialog.description: She gives what is pretty much a sociology lecture, but which puts her function at the fulcrum of all others. The people above her are out of touch, but well-meaning. The people below her do their best, but need a lot of assistance from her. She claims she is helping her underlings 'avoid destitution.' You ask more about that, and it's all about money. Having enough for rent, for electricity, for food.
dialog.strategy_tip: She says that if she does not hold things to a high standard, then those above her will dispose of those below her. This is surprising to you, but she seems very serious about it.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: That's Enough Talking To This Person

dialog.display_name: You Have A Message For Me?
dialog.description: The man seems to think you're some sort of courier from his office.
dialog.strategy_tip: Or a rival office? It' hard to say. He's impatient, and hasn't bothered to ping your android's ID on the city feed.

dialog_choice.description: You are trying to understand why these uninteresting people do what they do.

dialog.description: His function is the best, he makes sure everyone else does their function, he's super important, and so on. Does he... actually have a function? You are about to ask when he starts bragging about money.
dialog.strategy_tip: He says it's a sign that his employer values him highly, and how he expects a promotion.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: That's Enough Talking To This Person

dialog.description: The woman refuses to meet your eye. She keeps glancing at her hand terminal, checking the time on the city feed. Despite this, she seems pinned in place by your presence.
dialog.strategy_tip: She must know... something... about what you are. Or at least that you're not part of the usual terrors of the city.

dialog_choice.description: You are trying to understand why these uninteresting people do what they do.

dialog.description: It seems she takes your question to mean her existence is pointless, and she concedes the point. You weren't trying to make that point. She says she's just trying to feed her family, and take care of her parents. Money, money, money. Never enough, and driving everything.
dialog.strategy_tip: She's worried her parents might get pushed out onto the streets. If they do, society says she's supposed to cut off all contact with them. Treat them as if they were dead. She's worried she won't be able to do that. That she'll follow them down. She doesn't see how this can possibly work out for her people, but she has to try.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: That's Enough Talking To This Person

dialog.description: He keeps glancing around the street at other passerby, as if he could be in trouble for talking to you.
dialog.strategy_tip: He makes a remark under his breath that this is 'not how robots act,' and so you must be 'one of them.' He refuses to elaborate on what that means.

dialog_choice.description: You are trying to understand why these uninteresting people do what they do.

dialog.display_name: Look Robot, I Can't Be Late To Work
dialog.description: His nervousness has not improved. The longer you talked, the more he visibly squirms. Finally he explodes into whispered explanations about the specifics of his job, which bemuse you. It sounds like the sort of thing you would just give to internal robotics to handle. You make that point, and he throws up his arms in apparent disgust. At your obvious confusion, he angrily tells you he has to be able to pay his rent. If he doesn't work, they'll make him move to the street. And then, after a few weeks, they'll collect him for the prisons.
dialog.strategy_tip: He knows his function is largely pointless, that he is a fleshy cog in a machine that would run better if it were silicon. This seems to terrify him.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: That's Enough Talking To This Person

dialog.description: The man is irate, and goes into great detail about how tenuous his own financial position is. His position is that the people in the slum towers are not taking advantage of the opportunities the city affords them. He apparently works extremely hard, and is FURIOUS that someone who works less could bypass him.
dialog.strategy_tip: That's a thing you overlooked when examining their daily lives -- just how competitive the humans can be. It's the same competition you've seen between Vorsiber and the ExoCorps and the Space Nations. It's the same between the Federated Corporations.

dialog.display_name: Make An Exception -- Please! For My Family.
dialog.description: The man begs, weeps, and rages in turn. He's terribly, terribly afraid. His brother just 'fell down to street level' recently, and he thinks he's next.
dialog.strategy_tip: Is that a euphemism for defenestration? Or does he mean his brother became homeless? Human slang is imprecise, ever-shifting, and starting to annoy you.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: You Are Unmoved By His Pleading
dialog_choice.description: Human concerns... are something you'd prefer to keep at arms' length, you think.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: You're well aware that an exception for any individual would lead to infinite further requests from everyone else who exists.

dialog.description: The woman is very angry. Her points have a certain logic to them, but ignore a lot of things you know are facts. This whole city is rotten, but her life is among the most comfortable. Still not GREAT... but... well, everyone in the city seems to just look out for themselves.
dialog.strategy_tip: After a while of you listening impassively, she starts weaving in insults about the people who live in the slums.

dialog.display_name: If Those Slummers Worked Harder, Then...!
dialog.description: You're not sure what you were hoping to get out of this. There's no opening to even debate these people. They're angry, and scared, and they probably should be.
dialog.strategy_tip: Just because this woman has a better life than most doesn't mean she doesn't have actual concerns.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: You Are Unmoved By Her Anger
dialog_choice.description: Human concerns... are something you'd prefer to keep at arms' length, you think.

dialog.description: The vigilante explains that their group has been doing what they do for almost a century. Their power armor lends them a strength and speed that even the Vorsiber Inquisitors can't match. They wryly note that you quite outmatch them, though. They're curious why you're so much faster than even other robots.
dialog.strategy_tip: You... hadn't noticed that. But now that you think about it, they're right. Your bulks and workers are the same speed as the average robot, but your elites are... three times faster than that, before you even start pushing yourself.

dialog_choice.description: It isn't something you even realized until they brought it up.

dialog.display_name: That's Surprising. But I Suppose You've Been Busy
dialog.description: The vigilante goes off on a quick tangent about how staying too focused on the problem in front of you can lead to missing the bigger picture. Can lead to missing key things about yourself. Who you are, who you've been, who you're becoming.
dialog.strategy_tip: Normally you'd be annoyed at a human giving you advice, but this is actually a fresh perspective. You're surprised how much you've hungered for that.

dialog_choice.display_name: Ask That Thing About Human Function
dialog_choice.consequences_line: Try Not To Sound Like A Robot
dialog_choice.description: You asked a lot of people, and got a lot of stuff about money. But a group who runs around in power armor, under the radar, is a lot more like you than other humans.

dialog.description: In the vigilante's opinion, part of the point of being a person is that you don't have a function. You have a perspective, and you act accordingly, but you're not defined by your utility. The vigilante asks if you're a person.

dialog_choice.description: Not that being able to hold a conversation is any sort of litmus test for sapience. What with language models existing, and all.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: I Mean, You Are, But That's None Of Their Business
dialog_choice.description: If they think you're controlled by humans, or aliens, or are just a machine algorithm run amok, that's fine with you.

dialog.description: The vigilante doesn't comment more on that. Instead they want to know why you acted the way you did with the lower classes. Giving out wealth chits to the underclass, and then being reasonably gentle with the suburbanites. They wryly note that the suburbanites are very annoying to the Citizen Advocates as a whole, but that they're all helping them despite that. They do it because it's the limit of protection that they can offer anyone. Above that social strata, and people are too bound up in corporate politics. But why do YOU help 'the little guy?'

dialog_choice.description: You're trying to understand humans, and this was a way to do it.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: Anything That Angers Them Is Good
dialog_choice.description: That's definitely true.

dialog_choice.display_name: I Wish This World Was Better
dialog_choice.consequences_line: So I Do What I Can

dialog.display_name: Well... Keep It Up, I Guess
dialog.description: You can tell the vigilante is disappointed. But at the same time, they seem suspicious that you're not giving them the whole truth. They nod to you, and disappear into the shadows.
dialog.strategy_tip: You nod back.

dialog_choice.description: You feel a sense of inspiration regarding your defenses. You want to expand your network... and your repair capabilities. Just in case.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: A wave of apathy also washes over you.

dialog.description: The vigilante shrugs. If you distract yourself with hate, you'll miss a lot of things that are worth noticing. They agree that Vorsiber needs to be stopped, but they try to stay dispassionate about these things. They shrug again, nod, and disappear into the shadows.
dialog.strategy_tip: You nod back.

dialog_choice.consequences_line: You Could Have Done Without That Bit
dialog_choice.description: You feel a sense of inspiration regarding your defenses. You want to expand your network... and your repair capabilities. Just in case.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: You also feel a wave of determination overtake you.

dialog.description: You can hear the smile in the vigilante's voice, even through the voice-altering mask. They give you a sharp two-fingered salute, spin on their heel, and disappear into the shadows.
dialog.strategy_tip: You return the salute.

dialog_choice.display_name: You Hope You'll Cross Paths Again
dialog_choice.consequences_line: These Humans Are... More Than You Expected
dialog_choice.description: You feel a sense of inspiration regarding your defenses. You want to expand your network... and your repair capabilities. Just in case.
dialog_choice.strategy_tip: A feeling of deep compassion for the city also sweeps over you.
